intro: Gypsocallis procumbens, commonly known as the creeping gypsocallis, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its low-growing, spreading habit. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically white or pale pink in color. It thrives in well-drained soil and prefers full sun to partial shade. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it is not widely known outside of botanical circles.
